'''''Boletus auripes''''', commonly known as the '''butter-foot bolete''', is a species of [[bolete]] fungus in the family [[Boletaceae]]. First described from [[New York (state)|New York]] in 1898, the fungus is found in eastern Asia, Central America, and eastern North America from Canada to [[Florida]]. It is a [[mycorrhiza]]l species and typically grows in association with [[oak]] and [[beech]] trees.

The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] (mushrooms) formed by the fungus have convex to nearly flat [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] that are up to {{convert|13|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide. The [[stipe (mycology)|stems]] are up to {{convert|10|cm|in|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|3|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick, and feature reticulations (net-like ridges) on the upper portion. Other than the brownish upper cap, the entire surface of the mushroom is yellow. ''B. auripes'' is [[edible mushroom|edible]]. It can be distinguished from other similar yellow boletes by differences in color, degree of stem reticulation, and [[species distribution|distribution]].

==Taxonomy==
The species was originally [[species description|described]] by American mycologist [[Charles Horton Peck]] in 1898. Peck collected the [[type (biology)|type specimen]] in [[Port Jefferson, New York]].<ref name="Peck 1898"/> In 1945, [[Rolf Singer]] proposed the [[variety (botany)|variety]] ''Boletus auripes'' var. ''aureissimus'' as a [[Combinatio nova|new combination]] of the name ''Ceriomyces aureissimus'' described by [[William Alphonso Murrill]] in 1938;<ref name="Singer 1945"/> this [[taxon]] is now regarded as a distinct species under the name ''[[Boletus aureissimus]]''.<ref name="urlMycoBank: Boletus aureissimus"/> In 1936, [[Wally Snell]] reported finding a specimen of ''[[Boletus crassipes]]'', another species described by Peck from [[Mount Gretna, Pennsylvania]]. Snell suggested that although ''B. crassipes'' might be a valid species distinguished from ''B. auripes'' by a deeper brown cap color, yellow flesh that does not fade to white, and a stem with a more orange-yellow color and more extensive reticulation, he conceded that it was not clear that the [[morphology (biology)|morphological]] characteristics between the two did not overlap, and that further collections would be needed to clarify any differences between them.<ref name="Snell 1934"/> A couple of years later, he was more convinced of his stance and considered the two [[conspecific]]. The [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] authorities [[Index Fungorum]] and [[MycoBank]], however, do not recognize this putative [[synonym (biology)|synonymy]].<ref name="IndexFungorum: Boletus crassipes"/><ref name="urlMycoBank: Boletus crassipes"/>

In the genus ''Boletus'', ''B. auripes'' is [[classification (biology)|classified]] in [[section (biology)|section]] ''Appendiculati''. Species in this section are characterized by having a dry cap with a surface texture ranging from smooth to somewhat [[wikt:tomentose|tomentose]], yellow [[trama (mycology)|flesh]], a reticulate stem, and a mild taste. Other North American boletes in this section include ''[[Boletus speciosus]]'' and ''[[Boletus regius]]''.<ref name="Snell 1970"/>

The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''auripes'' means "golden yellow foot". It is [[common name|commonly]] known as the "butter-foot bolete".<ref name="Roody 2003"/>

==Description==
[[File:Boletus auripes 90459.jpg|thumb|left|The upper portion of the stem is reticulated.]]
The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of ''B. auripes'' has a convex shape before flattening somewhat in maturity, and attains a diameter of {{convert|4|–|13|cm|in|abbr=on}}. The cap surface is dry, with a texture ranging from finely [[Trichome#Plant trichomes|tomentose]] (hairy) to nearly smooth, and colored yellowish brown to [[chestnut (color)|chestnut]] brown or grayish brown. The cap color fades with age.<ref name="Bessette 2001"/> Similarly, the [[trama (mycology)|flesh]]—initially yellow—fades to whitish in maturity.<ref name="McIlvaine 1912"/> Unlike some other ''Boletus'' species, in ''B. auripes'' neither the surfaces nor the internal tissue turns blue when injured or exposed to air. The odor and taste of the mushroom are not distinctive.<ref name="Bessette 2001"/>

Initially pale yellow to yellow, the pore surface develops olive tinges as it matures, and often becomes depressed near the stem attachment. Pores are circular to angular, and minute—typically less than 1 mm wide; the tubes are {{convert|1|–|2.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} deep. The golden-yellow stem is {{convert|7|–|10|cm|in|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|2|–|3|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick. Young stems are typically bulbous to club-shaped, but this evens out somewhat as the mushroom grows, and mature stems are club-shaped to nearly equal in width throughout. The stem is dry, solid (i.e., not hollow), and features yellow reticulation, at least on the upper portion.<ref name="Bessette 2001"/> [[Mycelia]] at the base of the stem have a [[buff (color)|buff]] color.<ref name="Ortiz-Santana 2007"/> The fruit body does not have a [[partial veil]] or a [[annulus (mycology)|ring]] on the stem.<ref name="Bessette 2001"/>  ''Boletus auripes'' is [[edible mushroom|edible]].<ref name="urlMushroomExpert"/>

Mushrooms produce a [[spore print]]s that is yellow brown (especially in fresh prints) to olive brown. The smooth, yellowish [[spore]]s measure 10–14 by 3–5 [[micrometre|μm]], and range in shape from roughly elliptic to cylindric to subfusoid (somewhat spindle-shaped).<ref name="Bessette 2001"/> The [[basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) are club-shaped, four-spored, and measure 27.2–35.2 by 9.6–10.4 μm. The cellular arrangement of the [[cap cuticle]] is a trichodermium (whereby the outermost hyphae emerge roughly parallel, like hairs, perpendicular to the surface of the cap) consisting of erect [[hypha]]e with a diameter of 3.2–6.4 μm.<ref name="Ortiz-Santana 2007"/>

Field characteristics used to distinguish ''Boletus auripes'' from potential lookalike species include the yellowish brown to chestnut-brown cap surface that becomes paler with age, yellow flesh that does not stain blue, and a reticulate stem. ''[[Boletus aureissimus|B. aureissimus]]'' has a similar appearance, but has a honey-yellow to bright yellow or yellow-ochre cap, less conspicuous stem reticulation, and a more limited range covering Florida west to [[Texas]]. ''B. aureissimus'' var. ''castaneus'' has a purplish-brown cap with a texture like velvet.<ref name="Bessette 2001"/>

''Boletus auripes'' somewhat resembles ''[[Boletus aurantiosplendens|B. aurantiosplendens]]'', but the latter species has a more variably colored cap that can be orange, brownish orange, or yellowish, and variable degrees of stem reticulation.<ref name="Kuo: Boletes"/> ''[[Boletus hortonii|B. hortonii]]'' has a similar color scheme but lacks reticulation on the stem.<ref name="Roody 2003"/> ''B. auripes'' bears a superficial resemblance in coloration to the Costa Rican species ''[[Boletus lychnipes|B. lychnipes]]'', known only from a limited area in the northern [[Cordillera de Talamanca]]. The latter species may be distinguished by the lack of reticulations on the upper half of the stem, a brown or salmon-pink staining reaction on the stem in response to handling, and microscopically by a conspicuously sterile margin and prominent [[cystidia|pseudocystidia]].<ref name="Halling 1999"/> ''[[Retiboletus retipes]]'' is set apart from ''B. auripes'' by a darker cap, tubes that lack an olive tinge, and a stem that has more prominent reticulation extending down to the base. In contrast to ''B. auripes'', ''[[Boletus impolitus|B. impolitus]]'' has a floccose (wooly) or tomentose cap surface, and lacks an olive tinge on the tubes.<ref name="Snell 1970"/>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Boletus auripes'' is [[mycorrhiza]]l,<ref name="Roody 2003"/> and fruits singly, scattered, or in groups on the ground under broadleaf trees, especially [[oak]] and [[beech]],<ref name="Bessette 2001"/> but it has also been recorded associating with [[Kalmia latifolia|mountain laurel]] (''Kalmia latifolia'').<ref name="Snell 1970"/> ''Boletus auripes'' typically forms fruit bodies between June and November.<ref name="Bessette 2001"/>

''Boletus auripes'' has a [[disjunct distribution]], and is one of several fungi found in both eastern Asia and eastern North America. In North America, where it is relatively common, the range of the fungus extends from [[Alaska]] south to Mexico, and east to [[New York (U.S. state)|New York]].<ref name="Snell 1970"/><ref name="Bessette 2001"/><ref name="Jiménez 2001"/> In Central America, it has been recorded in [[Belize]].<ref name="Ortiz-Santana 2007"/> The mushroom has also been recorded from Taiwan,<ref name="Chen 1997"/> China (including [[Yunnan]], [[Sichuan]], [[Guangdong]], [[Kwangsi]], and [[Hunan]]), and Japan.<ref name="Hongo 1970"/><ref name="Taiwan"/> It was reported for the first time from the [[Russian Far East]] in 2008.<ref name="Bulakh 2008"/>
